hackathon-description-text: Take part in developing next-generation visualization applications and tools to make a difference in people’s lives. Over the last decade, information, simulation, and web-based technologies have greatly improved local, state and national government’s ability to respond to and prevent emerging disease outbreaks and improve population health. The MIDAS MISSION group is looking for teams of developers to create novel and innovative visualization applications for addressing important challenges in public health such as:

hackathon-requirements:
Teams should submit completed applications no later than midnight on Feb. 26.  Submissions formats will vary depending on the application, and teams will be responsible for making the visualization accessible to the judges.  The organizers will be monitoring the process during the hackathon period and will help facilitate any additional requirements that teams may need.

hackathon-rules:
Note: These Rules are subject to change.

All attendees, sponsors, partners, volunteers and staff at our hackathon are required to agree with the following code of conduct.
. Be kind to others. Do not insult or put down other attendees. Behave professionally. Remember that harassment and racist, sexist, or exclusionary jokes are not appropriate. Photography is encouraged, but other participants must be given a reasonable chance to opt out from being photographed.
. Consider and respect other people's opinions and beliefs. Everyone is entitled to their point of view and a diverse range of opinions and perspectives is one thing that allows us to create such innovative solutions at a rapid pace.
. We welcome attendees from all backgrounds and a hackathon is a great opportunity for learning and meeting new people. Be friendly, welcome and open with your fellow participants. Share your knowledge, expertise and opinions, and embrace those of other people. Consider open source licensing and use of open data and how code you are writing could be reused.
. Do your best and believe in yourself. A hackathon is an incredible experience for people of any ability level; everyone can make a valuable contribution. Not every project will be successful, but ideas that you believe in are worth trying. You could change the world, and if every one project that we build helps someone, saves a life or makes a positive difference, we have succeeded.

The MIDAS Public Health Hackathon (referred to as "Hackathon") is promoted and hosted by the MIDAS MISSION 2.0 Group and the Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center, which shall here on be referred to as the “organizers”. Affiliated organizations include the MIDAS Research Network, the MIDAS 2.0 Group, the MIDAS Informatics Services Group, the Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center, the University of Pittsburgh, and Carnegie Mellon University, which here on will be referred to as the “affiliates”. These terms and conditions govern your participation in the MIDAS Public Health Hackathon. hackathon-judging-criteria.judging-criterion: Applications will be first judged on whether they meet the requirements laid out the Requirements section of this page.  Applications not meeting this requirements will be immediately disqualified from further judging.
(Score 1-10) How novel is your visualization application or approach?  Does it present the public health data in new ways?

(Score 1-10) Does the application work as intended? Is the software easy to get up and running? How bug-free is the software? Given the short timeframe we do not expect well-polished software. Judging will be relative to other submissions.
(Score 1-10) How easy is it to use the application? How easy does the application make navigating the data? Is the presentation intuitive and understandable by a wide audience?
(Score 1-10) What is the potential for this application to impact public health awareness, response, and practice?
